quotes: president of the UN Security Council, in January 1976
Dr. Salim’s herculean efforts to restore China’s rightful seat at the United Nations in October 1971
It did, of course, cost him the UN secretary-general seat a decade later.
Dr. Salim issued a statement stepping aside in the balloting for the UN job on 9 December 1981.
After the unexpected death of Edward Sokoine on 12 April 1984, who was prime minister at the time,
speculation was rife that he would succeed the Father of the Nation to become the next president, in the 1985 ruling party presidential primary.
This would happen again in 1995,
and again in 2005.

events.notes: Clear linkage between time marker, organization, and role.

quotes: In July 1990 Dr. Salim submitted his first report to the Council of Ministers as secretary-general, titled “The Fundamental Changes Taking Place in the World and their Implications for Africa: Proposals for an African Response”.

Dr. Salim concluded his term of office as secretary-general in September 2001, but this was not the end of his efforts to promote African unity and cohesion, nor his attempts to resolve conflicts across the continent:
he was the AU special envoy to Darfur from 2005 to 2007 and was a member of the AU’s Panel of the Wise.

In November 2003 Dr. Salim was appointed by UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan as part of a group of eminent persons tasked with studying global security threats and recommending necessary changes and interventions.
From 2007 to 2019 Dr. Salim served on the board of the Mo Ibrahim Foundation and subsequently was also chair of the Foundation's Prize Committee.
His entry back into domestic politics was in November 2002 when President Benjamin Mkapa nominated him to become a member of the National Executive Committee of the ruling party.
In April 2005 Dr. Salim submitted his nomination form to contest for the Presidency under the ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM) ticket.

organizations.name: OAU
quotes: Though this was resisted by certain leaders, engagement with civil society increased over time.

His vision for the OAU was expressed in this report and although non-interference in the affairs of OAU member states continued to be observed, Dr. Salim felt it should not be construed to mean, or used to justify, indifference on the part of the OAU.

supporting_quotes: He has been the Permanent Representative of the United Republic of Tanzania to the United Nations since 1970

quotes: He has been the Permanent Representative of the United Republic of Tanzania to the United Nations since 1970
and Chairman of the Special Committee of 24 on decolonization since 1972
Mr. Salim is also the first Tanzanian Ambassador to Cuba (since July 1970)
as well as High Commissioner to Guyana (from December 1970)
Barbados (March 1971)
Jamaica (April 1971)
Trinidad and Tobago (July 1971)
Prior to his assignment at the United Nations, Mr. Salim served in 1969 as Ambassador to the People's Republic of China and to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea
Earlier, he served as Director of the African and Middle East Affairs Division of the Tanzanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1968 and 1969
High Commissioner to India from 1965 to 1568
Ambassador of Zanzibar to Egypt in 1964 and 1965
Mr. Salim served as Conference Director of the Ministerial Meeting of East and Central African States, held in Dar es Salaam in January 1969
Secretary-General at the Ministerial Conference of Non-Aligned States, held in Dar es Salaam in April of the following year
While serving at the United Nations, he was Chairman of the United Nations Special Mission to Niue in June/July 1972
Drafting Committee Chairman of the Political Committee of the Ministerial Conference of Non-Aligned States, Georgetown, Guyana (August 1972)
Chairman of the Political Committee of the International Conference of Experts in Support of the Victims of Colonialism and Apartheid in southern Africa, Oslo (April 1973)
1975 Chairman of the Security Council's Committee on Sanctions against Southern Rhodesia
President of the Security Council (January 1976)

events.notes: Clear appointment as Permanent Representative with specific time and location.

quotes: In 1964 Salim received his first official appointment with his posting as Tanzania’s ambassador to Egypt.
He was subsequently appointed as Tanzania’s High Commissioner to India from 1965 to 1968
and ambassador to the People’s Republic of China in 1969.
In January 1970, he was appointed as Tanzania’s Permanent Representative to the UN in New York, where he served for more than 10 years.
Salim is also the longest-serving secretary-general of the OAU, with a record three consecutive terms from 1989 until 2001
From 2004 to 2008, Salim served as the AU special envoy for Darfur.
Most recently, from 2007 to 2013, he served as a member of the AU’s Panel of the Wise

supporting_quotes: He was president of the 34th Session of the UNGA (1979);
events.notes: Leadership role in a specific session.

quotes: As Permanent Representative for over a decade, Salim headed various organs of the UN.
He was president of the 34th Session of the UNGA (1979);
of the 6th and 7th emergency special sessions of the UNGA (1980); and the 11th Special Session of the UNGA (1980).
in June/July 1972 he was chairman of the UN Special Mission to Niue
Drafting Committee member of the Political Committee of the Ministerial Conference of Non-Aligned States in Georgetown, Guyana, in August 1972;
chairman of the Political Committee of the International Conference of Experts for the Support of Victims of Colonialism and Apartheid in Southern Africa, based in Oslo, in April 1973.
He held this position from 1972 to 1980, and during this time the committee played a central role in steering many colonies and non-self-governing territories to full sovereignty and independence.
He was also chairman of the UN Security Council Committee on Sanctions against Southern Rhodesia (1975).
In January 1976, Salim served as the president of the UN Security Council.
He was chair of the High-Level Ad Hoc Group of the Special Committee on Decolonization, in April and May 1976,
and chair of the Drafting Committee of the Fifth Conference of Heads of States of Government of the Non-Aligned States, Colombo, in August 1976.
In May 1977 Salim was vice-president of the International Conference in Support of the Peoples of Zimbabwe and Namibia,
President of the International Conference on Sanctions against Apartheid in South Africa (1981),
President of the Paris International Conference against Apartheid (1984)

Diallo Telli, a national of Guinea, replaced Wodajo as secretary-general from 1964 to 1972.
Telli handed over the leadership of the OAU to Nzo Ekangaki, a Cameroonian, who led the organisation from 1972 to 1974.
Another Cameroonian, William Eteki, replaced Ekangaki and held the position of secretary-general from 1974 to 1978.
Subsequently, Edem Kodjo from Togo took over the leadership from 1978 to 1983.
Kodjo was succeeded by the then acting secretary-general, Peter Onu, a Nigerian, who served as the interim secretary-general from 1983 to 1985.
Ide Oumarou from Niger replaced Onu and led the OAU from 1985 to 1989.

Diallo Telli, a national of Guinea, replaced Wodajo as secretary-general from 1964 to 1972.
Telli handed over the leadership of the OAU to Nzo Ekangaki, a Cameroonian, who led the organisation from 1972 to 1974.
Subsequently, Edem Kodjo from Togo took over the leadership from 1978 to 1983.
Kodjo was succeeded by the then acting secretary-general, Peter Onu, a Nigerian, who served as the interim secretary-general from 1983 to 1985.
Ide Oumarou from Niger replaced Onu and led the OAU from 1985 to 1989.
Tanzania’s leaders had pleaded with Nigeria to support Onu as an official candidate for the post of secretary-general since he was the only alternative candidate to Oumarou.

Whether as an ambassador in Egypt, India or China in the 1960s; or a Permanent Representative at the United Nations in the 1970s; Minister of Foreign Affairs for my country in the 1980s; or secretary-general of the OAU in the 1990s; a member of the Panel of the Wise in the 2000s, my assignment, my working brief, the mission given to me has always been to promote, defend and realise Africa’s goals and ideals.
In that sense, I have been part of this institution since its first summit in 1964 in Cairo, Egypt.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.
GM Khadiagala, Allies in adversity: The frontline states in southern African security, 1975–1993, Athens: Ohio University Press, 1994, 25.

Excerpt from speech given by Salim at the UN on the eve of the UN Resolution on the Admission of China, 25 October 1971.
Diallo Telli, a national of Guinea, replaced Wodajo as secretary-general from 1964 to 1972.
Telli handed over the leadership of the OAU to Nzo Ekangaki, a Cameroonian, who led the organisation from 1972 to 1974.
Another Cameroonian, William Eteki, replaced Ekangaki and held the position of secretary-general from 1974 to 1978.
Subsequently, Edem Kodjo from Togo took over the leadership from 1978 to 1983.
Kodjo was succeeded by the then acting secretary-general, Peter Onu, a Nigerian, who served as the interim secretary-general from 1983 to 1985.
Ide Oumarou from Niger replaced Onu and led the OAU from 1985 to 1989.

Plenary Meeting Regarding the Expulsion of the South African Regime from the UNGA, 2 November 1974, New York.
Interview with Salim Ahmed Salim, 7 August 2014, Dar es Salaam.
Diallo Telli, a national of Guinea, replaced Wodajo as secretary-general from 1964 to 1972.
Telli handed over the leadership of the OAU to Nzo Ekangaki, a Cameroonian, who led the organisation from 1972 to 1974.
Subsequently, Edem Kodjo from Togo took over the leadership from 1978 to 1983.
Kodjo was succeeded by the then acting secretary-general, Peter Onu, a Nigerian, who served as the interim secretary-general from 1983 to 1985.
Ide Oumarou from Niger replaced Onu and led the OAU from 1985 to 1989.
Tanzania’s leaders had pleaded with Nigeria to support Onu as an official candidate for the post of secretary-general since he was the only alternative candidate to Oumarou.

Subsequently, Edem Kodjo from Togo took over the leadership from 1978 to 1983.
Kodjo was succeeded by the then acting secretary-general, Peter Onu, a Nigerian, who served as the interim secretary-general from 1983 to 1985.
Ide Oumarou from Niger replaced Onu and led the OAU from 1985 to 1989.

However, he was not able to acquire his ambassadorship – on 26 April 1964 Zanzibar and Tanganyika merged to form a union and Dr. Salim, with his credentials ready to be presented on behalf of Karume and Zanzibar, had to return to Dar es Salaam.

During the Zanzibar Revolution Dr. Salim was in China assisting with translations of a pictorial publication of Chinese history into Kiswahili.
Dr. Salim arrived in Cairo on 20 April 1964 to report as the new representative of the People’s Republic of Zanzibar.

However, he was not able to acquire his ambassadorship – on 26 April 1964 Zanzibar and Tanganyika merged to form a union and Dr. Salim, with his credentials ready to be presented on behalf of Karume and Zanzibar, had to return to Dar es Salaam.

In June of 1964 all foreign representatives of Zanzibar and Tanganyika were called back to Dar es Salaam. It was then that Dr Salim was officially appointed by President Nyerere to become the first ambassador of the Union of Zanzibar and Tanganyika, to Egypt.
Dr. Salim’s tenure in Egypt was not very long – in March 1965 was transferred to India as ambassador.

quotes: By April 1968 Dr. Salim had been called to serve back in Dar es Salaam, taking the position of director of African affairs at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Much of his time here was focused on explaining the government’s position when it recognised the independence of Biafra (on 13 April 1968).
In April 1969 Nyerere appointed Dr. Salim Tanzania’s ambassador to the People’s Republic of China.
So, in December 1969 at 27 years old, Dr Salim left China for New York, where his career on the global international stage began.

quotes: He has been the Permanent Representative of the United Republic of Tanzania to the United Nations since 1970
and Chairman of the Special Committee of 24 on decolonization since 1972
Mr. Salim is also the first Tanzanian Ambassador to Cuba (since July 1970)
as well as High Commissioner to Guyana (from December 1970)
Barbados (March 1971)
Jamaica (April 1971)
Trinidad and Tobago (July 1971)
Prior to his assignment at the United Nations, Mr. Salim served in 1969 as Ambassador to the People's Republic of China and to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea
Earlier, he served as Director of the African and Middle East Affairs Division of the Tanzanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1968 and 1969
High Commissioner to India from 1965 to 1568
Ambassador of Zanzibar to Egypt in 1964 and 1965
Mr. Salim served as Conference Director of the Ministerial Meeting of East and Central African States, held in Dar es Salaam in January 1969
Secretary-General at the Ministerial Conference of Non-Aligned States, held in Dar es Salaam in April of the following year
While serving at the United Nations, he was Chairman of the United Nations Special Mission to Niue in June/July 1972
Drafting Committee Chairman of the Political Committee of the Ministerial Conference of Non-Aligned States, Georgetown, Guyana (August 1972)
Chairman of the Political Committee of the International Conference of Experts in Support of the Victims of Colonialism and Apartheid in southern Africa, Oslo (April 1973)
1975 Chairman of the Security Council's Committee on Sanctions against Southern Rhodesia
President of the Security Council (January 1976)

The 1973 UN–OAU International Conference of Experts for the Support of Victims of Colonialism and Apartheid in Southern Africa, spearheaded at the request of the OAU and UN member states, was a landmark event that enabled liberation movements to participate on an equal footing, alongside NGOs and activists, with supportive governments and intergovernmental organisations at the same table.

The conference, which was motivated by the recommendations of Salim’s 1976 ad hoc committee to the FLS countries, which among others, recommended hosting another global solidarity conference in one of the newly liberated countries, was crucial, convening over 500 delegates from a large cross section of the international community.

Similarly, the 1977 International Conference in Support of the Peoples of Zimbabwe and Namibia, held in Maputo, Mozambique, was instrumental in mobilising global opinion in support of the international solidarity movement and coherently aligning the actions and programmes of the various stakeholders.

The consequent Maputo Programme of Action, which highlighted a significant unity in purpose and objectives among the delegates, became a core part of the OAU and UN’s policy programmes from 1977 for the liberation of Namibia and Zimbabwe.

quotes: In 1964 Salim received his first official appointment with his posting as Tanzania’s ambassador to Egypt.
He was subsequently appointed as Tanzania’s High Commissioner to India from 1965 to 1968
and ambassador to the People’s Republic of China in 1969.
In January 1970, he was appointed as Tanzania’s Permanent Representative to the UN in New York, where he served for more than 10 years.
Salim is also the longest-serving secretary-general of the OAU, with a record three consecutive terms from 1989 until 2001

time_markers.text: Upon my election as Chairperson of the AU Commission in 2012
quotes: Upon my election as Chairperson of the AU Commission in 2012, I consulted with a number of former leaders of the OAU and AU, and also requested to come and see Salim in Tanzania.
Chairperson of the African Union Commission  Addis Ababa, May 2015
Following in Nyerere’s footsteps, Salim advanced the moral, political and socio-economic justifications for African independence in the 1960s and 1970s.

And even before Tanzania’s independence in 1961, founding president Nyerere’s political party, the Tanganyika African National Union, had acknowledged the importance of an international alliance and solidarity in the fight against colonialism and oppression.

PAFMECA was formed in Mwanza, in September 1958 following a meeting between Nyerere, then leader of the Tanganyika African National Union, and other nationalist leaders from Kenya, Malawi, Uganda, Zanzibar and Zimbabwe.

label.label: Zanzibar Nationalist Party (ZNP)
label.involvement: Held roles including secretary-general of the youth wing and secretary of international relations.
label.reasoning: Early and significant political involvement in a key organization.

supporting_quotes: By his third year in secondary school Dr. Salim was attending political rallies involving the Zanzibar Nationalist Party (ZNP) and was later approached to become the secretary-general of the youth wing of the ZNP (the Youth Own Union).
He was 17 when he became secretary-general.
events.notes: Clear linkage between time, organization, and role.

time_markers.text: By his third year in secondary school
quotes: By his third year in secondary school Dr. Salim was attending political rallies involving the Zanzibar Nationalist Party (ZNP) and was later approached to become the secretary-general of the youth wing of the ZNP (the Youth Own Union).
In June 1961 Dr. Salim was selected to go to Cuba to open an office for the ZNP to advocate for Zanzibar's independence and to connect and build a network among fellow comrades.

Dr Salim stayed in Cuba from June 1961 to April 1962. It was while in Cuba that Dr Salim had his first exposure to the anti-apartheid movement in South Africa and was introduced to comrades from the African National Congress and South African Communist Party.
This was all during a span of four months, between August and October 1962.

quotes: In 2011 President Kikwete appointed Dr. Salim to serve on the country’s Constitutional Review Commission

In February 2013 Dr. Salim was appointed a member of the Central Committee (CC) of CCM – a position he held until retired from politics in 2018
Despite retiring from politics in 2018 Dr. Salim continued serving his country and Africa until falling ill in January 2019.

label.label: Joint Recognition from ISS, AU, ACCORD, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, and Mwalimu Nyerere Foundation
label.awarding_organization: Institute for Security Studies (ISS), African Union (AU), ACCORD, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, Mwalimu Nyerere Foundation
label.reasoning: Significant professional recognition from multiple prestigious organizations for contributions to security, peace, and development.

supporting_quotes: On 2 December 2014 the ISS, in collaboration with the AU, ACCORD, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, and the Mwalimu Nyerere Foundation will pay tribute to a wise man, freedom fighter and defender of peace and justice.
events.notes: Event is a tribute, which is a one-time recognition without ongoing responsibilities.

quotes: Salim served first as honorary patron and then as president of the Advisory Council of the Institute for Security Studies (ISS) since March 1997.
In this role he has guided and helped to shape the ISS over the past 17 years.

On 2 December 2014 the ISS, in collaboration with the AU, ACCORD, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, and the Mwalimu Nyerere Foundation will pay tribute to a wise man, freedom fighter and defender of peace and justice.

organizations.name: African Union (AU)
quotes: Union (AU), is firmly engaged with the democratisation process and its role is largely taken for granted.
membership of the AU’s Panel of the Wise.

On 2 December 2014 the ISS, in collaboration with the AU, ACCORD, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, and the Mwalimu Nyerere Foundation will pay tribute to a wise man, freedom fighter and defender of peace and justice.

organizations.name: OAU
quotes: After leaving the OAU, Salim settled into the role of national, African and world statesman, helping to resolve conflicts in Darfur and leading numerous election observer missions

organizations.name: Mwalimu Nyerere Foundation
quotes: Salim was elected the Chairman of the Mwalimu Nyerere Foundation soon after he returned to Tanzania and serves on numerous boards and councils such as the Mo Ibrahim Foundation.

roles.title: president of the Advisory Council of the Institute for Security Studies (ISS)
quotes: Salim served first as honorary patron and then as president of the Advisory Council of the Institute for Security Studies (ISS) since March 1997.
Salim was elected the Chairman of the Mwalimu Nyerere Foundation soon after he returned to Tanzania and serves on numerous boards and councils such as the Mo Ibrahim Foundation.
After leaving the OAU, Salim settled into the role of national, African and world statesman, helping to resolve conflicts in Darfur and leading numerous election observer missions
